STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 5, 2020
Juanita Bye
Melissa VanLuven
2218 Shunk Road
Sault Ste Marie, MI 49783
RE: License #: CN170201399
Sault Tribe Binogii - Placement
2218 Shunk Road
Sault Ste Marie, MI 49783
Dear Ms. Bye:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
June 4, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Courtney Atkins, Area Manager, at 517-599-3667.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 383-5531
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been
given an application for renewal of the license not less than
60 calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
Three foster home files were reviewed. One of 3 files documented that the renewal
application was sent to the foster parent on December 5, 2019 and the renewal was
due January 18, 2020. The application was sent less than 60 calendar days before
the expiration of the license.
R 400.12212 Personnel Records
(1) An agency shall maintain a personnel record for each staff
member.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(e) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following:
(i) The Michigan state police or the equivalent state or
Canadian provincial law enforcement agency where the
person usually resides.
Eleven employee files were reviewed. One of 11 files indicated that the employee
was hired on September 25, 2019 and the criminal background check was
completed on October 1, 2019. This is a second repeat violation. The original
violation was established during the renewal inspection completed on 06/25/18
and an acceptable CAP was received on 06/26/18. A repeat violation was
established during the interim inspection completed on July 23, 2019 and an
acceptable corrective action plan was received on August 28, 2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
4

ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans - Parent Signatures
Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’ supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are
not available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Six files and 15 service plans were reviewed. One of 6 files contained a service plan
dated October 17, 2019 and the plan was provided to the parent on December 17,
2019, one month beyond the 30-day time frame requirement.
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status and progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the
supervisor has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which
can be the monthly meeting. The Designated Performance
Standard for this Commitment is 95%, and the Floor
Performance Standard is 90%. This Commitment can become
eligible to move to structures and policies.
Six files and 15 service plans were reviewed. One file documented the last
supervision occurred on March 19, 2020. Supervision for April 2020 was missing.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 801 Medical Passport
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
• Quarterly.
• At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
5

• At or prior to each placement.
• Quarterly.
• Note: Foster care provider includes foster homes,
relative placements, detention, and residential facilities
Six files and 15 service plans were reviewed. One of 6 files lacked documentation
that the parent received a medical passport at the time the child was placed into the
parental home.
FOM 722-09 Foster Care – Updated Service Plans
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required
assessments (FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and
approved by the foster care supervisor only after a face-to-
face meeting with the foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date
Six files and 15 service plans were reviewed. One of six files contained a USP dated
November 21, 2019 that was signed by the supervisor on January 29, 2020,
exceeding the 14-day requirement for the signature.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined
in the following tables:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS
Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action
steps, safety concerns and the safety plan, and
any recommendations made for the family during
6

the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Six files and 15 service plans were reviewed. Two of 6 files lacked documentation of
FTM’s being conducted or, the DHHS-1105 was not used to document the FTM.
One file documented that FTM’s occurred on June 11, 2019 and July 15, 2019
however, the DHHS-1105 form was missing from the file. One file documented that
an ISP was completed on February 3, 2020 and an FTM was conducted on April 28,
2020. The FTM was not conducted prior the completion of the ISP.
This is a third repeat violation. The original violation was established during
the interim inspection completed on June 28, 2017 and an acceptable
corrective action plan was received on August 30, 2017. A repeat violation was
established during the renewal inspection completed on 06/25/18 and an
acceptable CAP was received on 06/26/18. A second repeat violation was
established during the interim inspection completed on July 23, 2019 and an
acceptable corrective action plan was received on August 28, 2019.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent-agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
The foster parent/caregiver must be included in the PATP
process. The foster parent/caregiver signature is required and
indicates that the foster parent/caregiver acknowledges and
agrees to the activities required to meet the needs of the child
in their care.
Six files and 15 service plans were reviewed. Four of 6 files lacked documentation
that the foster parent received the PATP or, they received the plan late, beyond the
required 30-day time frame requirement. One file contained a PATP dated
November 13, 2019 that lacked signatures. The same file contained a PATP dated
August 15, 2019 and the foster parent signed the plan on October 4, 2019. A second
file contained a PATP dated October 17, 2019 and the foster parent signed the plan
on December 9, 2019. A third file contained a PATP dated November 21, 2019 and
the foster parent signed the plan on January 30, 2020. A fourth file contained a
PATP dated January 3, 2020 and the foster parent signed the plan on April 16,
2020.
FOM 722-06H Timely Entry of Contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
• Any face-to-face contact with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
7

• Foster care caseworker/supervisor.
• CPS caseworker/supervisor.
• Adoption caseworker/supervisor.
• Permanency resource monitors.
• Education planners.
• Michigan Youth Opportunities Initiative coordinators.
• Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
• Sibling face-to-face contacts.
All other case contacts must be entered prior to the report
period end date on the applicable case service plan.
Six files and 15 service plans were reviewed. One of 6 files documented 2 contacts
that were entered into MISACWIS late. One contact occurred on January 3, 2020
and the contact was entered on January 13, 2020. A second contact occurred on
February 4, 2020 and was entered on February 18, 2020.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was not required at this time.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
8

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
A corrective action plan was received on August 28, 2019 in response to those
policy and rule violations established during the interim inspection completed on July
23, 2019. There were no special investigations during the licensing period.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
June 5, 2020
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
________________________________________
Date
Area Manager
9
